question: 6 (a)
sols_html:
Assume towards a contradiction that

\(\displaystyle \sqrt{3} + \sqrt{2} = \frac{p}{q}\)

where \(\displaystyle \gcd(p,q) = 1\). Now, squaring both sides yields

\(\displaystyle 3 + 2\sqrt{6} + 2 = \frac{p^{2}}{q^{2}}\)

and isolating for the radical yields

\(\displaystyle \sqrt{6} = \frac{p^{2}-5q^{2}}{2q^{2}}\)

Now the right hand side is rational so now it suffices to show that \(\displaystyle \sqrt{6}\) is irrational (this will simplify the computations to treat this as its own case). Suppose that

\(\displaystyle \sqrt{6} = \frac{a}{b}\)

where \(\displaystyle \gcd(a,b) = 1\). Squaring both sides and cross multiplying yields

\(\displaystyle 6b^{2} = a^{2}\)

Now, 2 divides the left hand side so \(\displaystyle 2 \mid a\) writing \(\displaystyle a = 2A\) and substituting yields

\(\displaystyle 6b^{2} = 4A^{2}\).

Dividing by 2 yields

\(\displaystyle 3b^{2} = 2A^{2}\).

Now, 2 divides the right hand side so \(\displaystyle 2 \mid b\). This contradicts the fact that \(\displaystyle \gcd(a,b) = 1\) since 2 divides both numbers. Thus \(\displaystyle \sqrt{6}\) is irrational and hence so is \(\displaystyle \sqrt{3} + \sqrt{2}\) by the above argument as required.
